reviewText:
My 8 year old daughter says "I love it and it was great"

It showed beautiful places and was very informative about traveling in and around the great barrier reef.

Not much new info, at least to me. I was wanting more of a true travel show, but I honestly felt like this was more of a wake up the reef is in trouble show. Which isn't bad, just not what I was wanting right now.

Travel Wild - The Great Barrier Reef is a documentary about the Great Barrier Reef, which is conducted by the acclaimed adventurer and environmentalist Lin Sutherland. It provides an introductory overview of the Great Barrier Reef, which is located in the Coral Sea, off the coast of Queensland, Australia, and which is the largest coral reef system in the world. This documentary features footage of breathtaking underwater scenery and amazing marine life, as well as some distinctive and unique land animals. There is a strong emphasis on responsible travel and tourism practices, environmental protection and preservation, long-term sustainability, and the maintenance of the natural ecological balance. Travel Wild - The Great Barrier Reef is an excellent travel documentary, which is decidedly interesting, informative, and educational, and which merits a five-star rating, along with an enthusiastic recommendation.
Great if you like to scuba dive.
The video had provided a lot of knowledge,  but I was expecting more focus on diving in the area and there was little discussion of that.
Excelente documental sobre las islas de Australia y the grand barrier. Learned a Lot. Love the ocano. Recomend to watch if you Love the ocano.

Starts off by telling us that scientist predicts that the coral reefs will be gone by 2050. Important to have responsible tourism.

Several places visited:
1. Lizard Island, designed around nature. Off of this island is where you can see the Potato Cod. Coral Reefs are like underwater cities.
Some political speech in this section!

2. Wilson Island, turtle hotspot. Only 12 people allowed on the island at one time.

3. Heron Island which is in an atoll. When you land on Heron Island you have to attend a compulsory nature brief. There are hundreds of thousands of birds on this island most of which are not bothered by the sight of humans. The wreck of HMS Protector is close to the island. This island used to have a sea turtle soup factory and then became a place to ride the turtles. In 1943 the island was made a turtle reserve. No turtle riding allowed now! Interesting to see the turtle lay her eggs and then later to see the hatchlings all scurrying down to the shore.

Quite a bit of talk about climate change.

We watched this as a part of our homeschool week long study on oceans and coral reefs. Some beautiful filming.

Wonderfully done and quite beautiful.  I will watch this one again and share it with my friends.  I have already shared this one:

http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00H8V0ZRW/ref=cm_sw_r_fa_dp_jBo5sb13YQS6Y which is Sea of Creepy Monsters.  It's a great one too.
